articles.title: This Ghanaian barrister is building bridges between law, feminism, and social change
articles.summary: "I can be a lawyer with a gendered lens, a development expert with a gendered lens, a political scientist with a gendered lens, and a professor with a gendered lens."
articles.content:
“My name is Jarpa Dawuni, and I often shorten it as J. Jarpa because my first name is actually Josephine,” she explains. “But in an attempt to decolonize in every aspect, I hyphenated it — Josephine-Jarpa — and I use Jarpa, which is my ‘native’ or local name from Ghana.”

From the start, Dr. Jarpa Dawuni makes clear that identity for her is an act of agency. She resists being reduced to a single role. Smiling at the impossibility of being contained she says:

I would describe myself as a feminist, a womanist, a mother, an aunt, a social activist, a professor, a lawyer, and the list goes on.

That layered self-description is not a rhetorical flourish; it is the lived reality of a Ghanaian barrister turned political scientist, institution-builder at Howard University, and founder of the Institute for African Women in Law (IAWL). Across each role runs a consistent thread: the conviction that women’s voices belong at the center of law, leadership, and social transformation.

The matriarch’s legacy

Dawuni traces her first lessons in resistance and self-knowledge to her grandmother, the matriarch of her family. She recalls: “She had a strong sense of knowing who she was, knowing what was good for her, what she would stand up for, what she would not stand up for.” Though her grandmother had no formal education, she commanded authority and transmitted values of dignity and excellence to her children and grandchildren.

This legacy shaped how Dawuni understood activism: not as the work of elites, but as something embedded in family life and “part of the DNA.” She describes watching her grandmother’s spirit echoed in her mother, her aunties, and now in her own role as a mother and auntie.

Everybody has the power to be an activist — whether it flourishes often depends on the environment.

From law to scholarship

Her professional journey mirrors that conviction. Dawuni is a qualified barrister-at-law before the Ghana Superior Courts and holds a PhD in political science from Georgia State University. She went on to join Howard University, where she is now a Full Professor of Political Science. Her research spans judicial politics, women in the legal professions, gender and law, democratization, and international human rights.

What unites this range is her insistence on a gendered lens. She explains:

I can be a lawyer with a gendered lens, a development expert with a gendered lens, a political scientist with a gendered lens, and a professor with a gendered lens.

That orientation led her to notice a glaring silence in the literature: the absence of sustained work on African women in law.

I started looking into research on African women in law, and I really couldn’t find much. So I began to write.

The result has been a prolific and field-shaping body of work. She has also conducted fieldwork in more than ten African countries, as well as the United Kingdom and Brazil, documenting stories that otherwise would have remained invisible. She reflects:

I remembered Toni Morrison’s line: if there’s a book you want to read and it hasn’t been written, then you must write it. That’s what I did.

A social entrepreneur in academia

For Dawuni, research is only one side of her activism. “I call myself a social entrepreneur. I create stuff, I fill in gaps where there’s a gap.”

One of her proudest examples is at Howard University. When she arrived in 2015, she discovered there was no program devoted to women and gender studies. She began by organizing small initiatives — an International Women’s Day program here, a faculty collective there — but funding was scarce. Then one day the university president called: “Send me a proposal by 10 a.m. tomorrow.”

She laughs at the memory. “Less than 24 hours! But because I’d been percolating ideas for years, I sat down, didn’t sleep, and wrote the proposal.”

She initially asked for USD 30,000. The president suggested USD 250,000. By the time the negotiations concluded, she had secured USD 1 million — during the early months of the pandemic, no less. With that support, she founded the Center for Women, Gender, and Global Leadership, the first of its kind at Howard.

Her ability to translate vision into resources is part of a wider record: she has raised millions in grants and fellowships, including as Principal Investigator of a major National Science Foundation study on Black and Afro-descendant women judges. She has also been recognized internationally, receiving the Women in Law Academia International Award in Austria and the White House Presidential Award for her service on the board of the African Research Academies for Women.

Her lesson is clear:

Be prepared, so when the opportunity comes, you’re ready to hit gold. And don’t let people down when they call on you.

African feminism, womanism, and contextual equality

When asked to define her feminism, Dawuni is pragmatic but precise.

For me, feminism is simply the idea of equality of the sexes. But my reality as an African woman is different from my African-American sister who was born and raised as a Black woman in Louisiana. There may be commonalities, but there are also differences.

She often uses feminism and womanism interchangeably.

If the word feminism will not necessarily fly with some people, I have to be respectful of that. Womanism is rooted in African systems of womanhood and the communal nature of our lived experiences.

This fluidity is strategic: she builds bridges across communities, while refusing the universalizing assumptions of Western feminism.

Her work links African feminist thought to broader struggles of “third world feminists” — from Chicana to Asian to African thinkers — resisting racialized and colonial hierarchies in the feminist canon. Through her research, she has developed matri-legal feminism, a theoretical approach that centers the African matriarchal experience in the legal feminist discourse.

Research, resilience, and grassroots impact

Dawuni is candid about her doubts. “Sometimes I sit down and think, oh, my research and my activism are so elitist because I’m dealing with judges, lawyers, academics.” But she insists that elites, too, are subject to patriarchy — and shaping their consciousness can have ripple effects. “The multiplicative effect matters,” she explains.

If we are able to support women in law, and these women are gender-focused and minded, they will support other women. If judges are trained to recognize gendered dimensions of the law, if lawyers understand that what they thought was just ‘colleague play’ is actually harassment, then their clients and communities feel the impact.

Behind these professional achievements lies a story of perseverance through difficulty. Balancing motherhood, teaching, and research, Dawuni also endured profound personal losses during her doctoral studies. Rather than halting her trajectory, she channeled those experiences into her scholarship and activism. She recalls: “Through it all, I still finished my PhD. Everything I do, I remember my sister, I remember my mother. I’m doing it in their honor and just to keep pushing on in life.”

Her resilience underscores a lesson she shares often with younger scholars: success is rarely linear.

People admire the blossoms but forget the roots. Success is like that. The roots are in the hard, painful, unseen work.

Advice for the next generation

For those just starting out, Dawuni emphasizes the importance of self-inspiration and preparation. She recounts how small encounters with women role models shaped her sense of what was possible.

In 1994, she read an Ebony magazine profile of Dr. Nanette Graham, a young professor and lawyer. Inspired, she cut out Graham’s picture and still keeps it almost thirty years later. A year later, she met Ghanaian lawyer Adeline Araba Ainooson. Dawuni admired her elegance and asked for a picture of her call to the bar. Araba sent one, writing on the back, “I hope it inspires you.” It did — and the two are still close friends today.

These early encounters became her compass.

Initially, I appeared to be lost — friends and family asked, ‘What do you really want to do — law, development work, or politics?’ But a common thread that ran through all my degrees was my passion for women’s and children’s rights. I decided to weave a mosaic from my interdisciplinary training in law, development, and politics. I chose academia — a profession that has allowed me to engage in research and to use my scholarship to promote activism for gender equity in law and access to justice.

As she explains, storytelling itself is a form of activism. “My goal is to move from the oral tradition of storytelling to the written tradition of documentation — to historicize women in law.”

Her advice to younger generations is straightforward:

She started as a barrister in Ghana, earned a PhD in political science, and became a full professor. Dr. Jarpa Dawuni’s work blends law, feminism, and education to create lasting change for African women and gender equality in the legal world.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une avocate ghanéenne relie droit, féminisme et changement social
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La Dre Jarpa Dawuni est une avocate et professeure ghanéenne qui combine son travail en droit, science politique et activisme pour promouvoir l’égalité des sexes. Elle veille à ce que la voix des femmes soit entendue dans le droit et le leadership, surtout en Afrique.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
La Dre Dawuni a fondé l’Institut pour les femmes africaines en droit et créé le Centre pour les femmes, le genre et le leadership mondial à l’Université Howard. Elle a commencé comme avocate au Ghana, obtenu un doctorat en science politique, puis est devenue professeure titulaire. Elle a remarqué un manque de recherches sur les femmes africaines en droit, alors elle a commencé à écrire et à mener des études dans plusieurs pays. Elle a aussi obtenu des financements importants pour soutenir des programmes axés sur le genre.

**Impact**
Son travail est important car il met en lumière les expériences des femmes africaines en droit, un sujet souvent ignoré. En combinant féminisme et idées culturelles africaines, elle crée des liens entre communautés. Elle aide à former juges et avocats à comprendre les questions de genre, ce qui peut améliorer la justice pour beaucoup. Ses efforts ont mené à de nouveaux programmes universitaires et à une reconnaissance internationale.

**Prochaine étape**
La Dre Dawuni prévoit de continuer à développer la recherche et l’activisme pour les droits des femmes en droit. Elle encourage les jeunes chercheurs à bien se préparer et à suivre leur passion. Son travail vise à documenter les histoires des femmes en droit et à promouvoir plus d’égalité dans le monde.

**En une phrase**
Le travail de la Dre Jarpa Dawuni mêle droit, féminisme et éducation pour créer un changement durable en faveur des femmes africaines et de l’égalité des sexes dans le domaine juridique.

articles.title: Catherine calls for end to 'stigma' around addiction
articles.summary: The message from the Princess of Wales comes on Addiction Awareness Week.
articles.content:
Catherine calls for end to 'stigma' around addiction

3 hours ago Share Save Noor Nanji Culture reporter Share Save

PA Media

The Princess of Wales has called for an end to the "stigma" surrounding addiction, and urged people to offer "empathy and support" to those dependent on alcohol, drugs or gambling. Catherine, who sent the message to mark Addiction Awareness Week, said "significant progress" has been made to better understand addiction, but warned more needs to be done. The princess is the patron of The Forward Trust, a charity that tries to break the cycle of addiction and is behind the campaign running from 23-30 November. Catherine, who has also campaigned on mental health issues, draws parallels between the two conditions in her message.

She said addiction was "not a choice or a personal failing, but a complex mental health condition that should be met with empathy and support. She added: "But still, even now in 2025, people's experience of addiction is shaped by fear, shame and judgement. This needs to change. "The stigma surrounding those who face addiction allows it to thrive behind closed doors, impacting families and communities, and ultimately ruining lives." The princess said that many people will know someone who is struggling with addiction. "Now is the moment to show our compassion and love to help them, or their friends and family, to reach out to organisations like The Forward Trust for support," she said. "Recovery is hard, but with the right treatment it is possible. And this begins with a conversation, a listening ear and showing we care." Catherine launched the first Addiction Awareness Week in 2021 on behalf of the trust and its Taking Action on Addiction campaign. She concluded her message by urging people to have open conversations to bring addiction and the harm it causes "out of the shadows".

PA Media Catherine launched the charity's campaign in 2021
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant and positive advocacy effort by the Princess of Wales to reduce stigma around addiction, promoting empathy, support, and mental health understanding. This has broad societal impact by encouraging open conversations and support for those affected by addiction, which can lead to improved recovery outcomes and reduced social harm. The story focuses on a meaningful campaign with clear context and ongoing efforts, making it an inspiring good news story.
articles.personality_title: Princess Catherine urges kindness and support for people facing addiction
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Addiction Awareness Week is a time to focus on understanding addiction better and helping people who struggle with it. The Princess of Wales, Catherine, has been involved with this cause since 2021 through her work with The Forward Trust, a charity that helps people break free from addiction.

She reminded everyone that addiction is a mental health condition, not a choice or failure. Her message asked people to show empathy, support, and kindness to those dealing with problems like alcohol, drugs, or gambling.

**Impact** – Catherine’s call is important because many people with addiction feel judged and keep their struggles hidden. This stigma makes it harder for them to get help. By encouraging open conversations and understanding, her message helps families and communities support recovery. It also highlights that with the right treatment and care, people can recover from addiction.

**What's next step** – The Forward Trust and its campaign will continue to promote awareness and support for addiction. Catherine’s message encourages more people to talk openly about addiction and reach out to organizations for help. This could lead to more people getting the treatment they need and less stigma in society.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Princess Catherine is urging everyone to treat addiction with kindness and support, helping people feel safer to seek help and recover.

articles.title: Kos: The Western Balkans belongs to the EU on an equal basis
articles.summary: The Commissioner for Kosovo participated in the summit of Western Balkan leaders in Tirana.
articles.content:
TIRANA – EU Commissioner for Enlargement, Marta Kos, assessed that the entire Western Balkans belongs to the European Union on an equal basis, with full rights. She stated this at the opening of the Summit of Western Balkan and EU leaders taking place today in Tirana, which is also attended by the Prime Minister of Serbia, Đuro Macut. “Our ambition is for all of you to progress in harmony, so we do not want any of you to lag behind, because ultimately, the entire Western Balkans belongs to the European Union, as equal members – with full rights, as recognition for full alignment with EU laws and values,” said Kos, adding that the focus should be on how to accelerate reforms.

Speaking about the Growth Plan, she emphasized that it is crucial to establish economic alignment of the Western Balkans with EU countries. “We know from experience that as a candidate country approaches EU accession, more tourists come, media presence in the EU increases, and curiosity among citizens of member states grows. Let us use the remaining two years (of the Growth Plan) to make the Growth Plan a great success and prepare the ground for your EU accession, as the main goal of the Growth Plan is to help you develop so that you can become an equal member of the European Union in the future,” Kos told the leaders of the Western Balkans. She noted that the Growth Plan has brought a new dynamic to the integrations and added that the Western Balkans is already part of Europe, and it remains to be institutionally confirmed. Albanian Prime Minister Edi Rama stated in his opening address that the Western Balkans is important as it has decided to move forward together, with the Growth Plan as a common roadmap, but, as he says, not only towards Brussels, but towards the freedoms and opportunities of a unique European market.

Rama assessed that the Western Balkans has never experienced reforms of this level of transformation and stated that the region strives to grow with Europe, not at its expense, proving daily that it belongs to the EU. (November 21)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant political development where the EU Commissioner emphasizes equal membership and rights for the Western Balkans in the European Union, highlighting efforts to accelerate reforms and economic alignment. This has broad societal and political implications for regional integration, stability, and the advancement of democratic values and freedoms, benefiting millions in the region.
articles.personality_title: EU Commissioner affirms equal membership for Western Balkans in the European Union
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Western Balkans is a group of countries in Southeast Europe working to join the European Union (EU). Leaders from these countries and the EU met in Tirana to discuss their future together.

**What happened** – On November 21, Marta Kos, the EU Commissioner for Enlargement, spoke at a summit in Tirana with Western Balkan leaders, including the Prime Minister of Serbia, Đuro Macut. She said the whole Western Balkans region belongs to the EU as equal members with full rights. Kos emphasized the need to speed up reforms and economic alignment with the EU through the Growth Plan, which aims to prepare these countries for EU membership.

**Impact** – This is important because it shows the EU’s clear commitment to treating Western Balkan countries as equals, not just candidates. The Growth Plan encourages economic growth and cooperation, which can bring more tourists, media attention, and business opportunities to the region. It also supports reforms that help build stronger democracies and better laws, benefiting millions of people.

**What's next step** – The next two years will focus on making the Growth Plan successful by helping Western Balkan countries align their economies and laws with the EU. This work will prepare them for joining the EU as full members in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU Commissioner confirmed that the Western Balkans are equal partners in Europe’s future, with a clear plan to support their full membership in the European Union.
articles.personality_title_fr: La commissaire européenne affirme l’égalité d’adhésion des Balkans occidentaux à l’Union européenne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les Balkans occidentaux sont un groupe de pays d’Europe du Sud-Est qui cherchent à rejoindre l’Union européenne (UE). Les dirigeants de ces pays et de l’UE se sont réunis à Tirana pour discuter de leur avenir commun.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 21 novembre, Marta Kos, commissaire européenne chargée de l’élargissement, s’est exprimée lors d’un sommet à Tirana avec les dirigeants des Balkans occidentaux, dont le Premier ministre serbe Đuro Macut. Elle a déclaré que toute la région des Balkans occidentaux appartient à l’UE en tant que membres égaux avec tous les droits. Kos a souligné la nécessité d’accélérer les réformes et l’alignement économique avec l’UE grâce au Plan de Croissance, qui vise à préparer ces pays à l’adhésion.

**Impact** – Cela est important car cela montre l’engagement clair de l’UE à considérer les Balkans occidentaux comme des partenaires égaux, pas seulement comme des candidats. Le Plan de Croissance favorise la croissance économique et la coopération, ce qui peut attirer plus de touristes, de médias et d’opportunités commerciales dans la région. Il soutient aussi des réformes qui renforcent les démocraties et améliorent les lois, au bénéfice de millions de personnes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les deux prochaines années seront consacrées à la réussite du Plan de Croissance en aidant les pays des Balkans occidentaux à aligner leurs économies et leurs lois sur celles de l’UE. Ce travail préparera leur adhésion complète à l’UE à l’avenir.

**Phrase clé** – La commissaire européenne a confirmé que les Balkans occidentaux sont des partenaires égaux dans l’avenir de l’Europe, avec un plan clair pour soutenir leur pleine adhésion à l’Union européenne.
articles.personality_title_es: La comisaria de la UE afirma la igualdad de los Balcanes Occidentales en la Unión Europea
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los Balcanes Occidentales son un grupo de países del sureste de Europa que buscan unirse a la Unión Europea (UE). Los líderes de estos países y de la UE se reunieron en Tirana para hablar sobre su futuro juntos.

**Qué pasó** – El 21 de noviembre, Marta Kos, la comisaria de la UE para la Ampliación, habló en una cumbre en Tirana con líderes de los Balcanes Occidentales, incluido el primer ministro de Serbia, Đuro Macut. Dijo que toda la región pertenece a la UE como miembros iguales con plenos derechos. Kos destacó la necesidad de acelerar las reformas y la alineación económica con la UE mediante el Plan de Crecimiento, que prepara a estos países para ser miembros.

**Impacto** – Esto es importante porque muestra el compromiso claro de la UE de tratar a los Balcanes Occidentales como socios iguales, no solo como candidatos. El Plan de Crecimiento fomenta el crecimiento económico y la cooperación, lo que puede atraer más turistas, medios y oportunidades de negocio a la región. También apoya reformas que fortalecen las democracias y mejoran las leyes, beneficiando a millones de personas.

**Próximo paso** – Los próximos dos años se centrarán en hacer que el Plan de Crecimiento tenga éxito ayudando a los países de los Balcanes Occidentales a alinear sus economías y leyes con las de la UE. Este trabajo preparará su adhesión completa a la UE en el futuro.

**Frase clave** – La comisaria de la UE confirmó que los Balcanes Occidentales son socios iguales en el futuro de Europa, con un plan claro para apoyar su plena membresía en la Unión Europea.

articles.content:
Click to expand Image A protester writes "dignity" in English and Chinese in a show of solidarity with the White Paper protest in China at the University of Washington in Seattle, December 4, 2022. © 2022 Chin Hei Leung/SOPA Images/Sipa USA via AP Photo

Three years ago, a series of protests in China has sparked a political awakening among Chinese youth, with many questioning Chinese leader Xi Jinping’s authoritarian policies and practices and notably confronting the government’s abuses against Tibetans and Uyghurs.

In response to a deadly apartment fire in Urumqi, Xinjiang, blamed on harsh Covid-19 restrictions, thousands in Shanghai, Beijing, and other cities took to the streets in November 2022. They defied Xi’s draconian “Zero-Covid” policy, chanting “We want human rights” and “Down with the Communist Party.” As an act of wordless resistance and opposition to censorship, demonstrators held up blank sheets of paper, thus becoming known as the White Paper protests, China’s largest nationwide demonstrations since Tiananmen in 1989.

Although the government was already easing its zero-Covid policy, the protests accelerated its end.

The authorities arrested a number of protesters. Most were soon released, but a young Uyghur student, Kamile Wayit, was sentenced to three years in prison for “promoting extremism” after sharing a video of the protests online. A filmmaker, Chen Pinlin (陈品霖), was sentenced to three-and-a-half years for his documentary, “Urumqi Middle Road.”

The political awakening has also been visible among young Chinese diaspora: in New York City, for example, last year’s White Paper anniversary featured “East Turkestan” flags, which represent a Uyghur independence movement, along with Palestinian flags, reflecting a desire to be part of a broader movement.

These current demonstrations contrast sharply with the nationalism of past protests in China, which defended the government’s abuses against Tibetans during the 2008 Beijing Olympics, and supported brands linked to Uyghur forced labor in 2021.

Some diaspora youths have become organized. Chinese Youth Stand for Tibet aims to promote Tibetan culture within Chinese-speaking communities and address ethnic conflicts and prejudice, including “majority ethnic Han chauvinism.” The authorities have noticed. In July, they arrested Tara Zhang Yadi, a France-based student activist and White Paper participant who had returned to China, for her advocacy of Tibetan rights.

The White Paper protests ignited a generation imagining freedom, respect for basic rights, and solidarity across borders that the arrest and detention of young activists are unlikely to extinguish.

It highlights a growing movement for human rights and solidarity across borders, with meaningful societal impact beyond a small niche. Despite ongoing repression, the protests have inspired hope and activism for freedom and dignity, fulfilling criteria for inspiring good news in human rights.
articles.personality_title: White Paper protests spark youth awakening and push for human rights in China
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In late 2022, a deadly fire in a city in China called Urumqi happened during strict Covid-19 lockdowns. Many people blamed the harsh rules for making it hard to escape the fire. This led to big protests across several Chinese cities.

**What happened** – Thousands of people, mostly young, protested against the government’s strict Covid policy and called for human rights. They held up blank white sheets of paper to show their anger without using words, which became a symbol known as the White Paper protests. These were the largest protests in China since 1989.

**Impact** – The protests helped speed up the end of the government’s strict Covid rules. They also sparked political awareness among young people in China and in Chinese communities abroad. Some young activists have started groups to support Tibetan culture and speak up against unfair treatment. However, the government arrested some protest leaders, showing the risks involved.

**What's next step** – Despite arrests, the movement continues to grow quietly. Young activists are likely to keep pushing for rights and fairness. The protests have opened up new conversations about freedom and solidarity that could influence future changes in China and beyond.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The White Paper protests have inspired a new generation of young people in and outside China to stand up for human rights and challenge unfair policies.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les manifestations du Papier blanc éveillent la jeunesse chinoise et réclament les droits humains
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Fin 2022, un incendie mortel dans la ville chinoise d’Urumqi a eu lieu pendant des confinements stricts liés au Covid-19. Beaucoup ont accusé ces règles sévères d’avoir empêché les gens de s’échapper de l’incendie. Cela a déclenché de grandes manifestations dans plusieurs villes chinoises.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des milliers de personnes, surtout des jeunes, ont protesté contre la politique stricte du Covid et ont demandé des droits humains. Ils tenaient des feuilles blanches vides pour montrer leur colère sans parler, ce qui est devenu un symbole appelé les manifestations du Papier blanc. Ce furent les plus grandes manifestations en Chine depuis 1989.

**Impact** – Ces manifestations ont aidé à accélérer la fin des règles strictes contre le Covid. Elles ont aussi éveillé une conscience politique chez les jeunes en Chine et dans les communautés chinoises à l’étranger. Certains jeunes militants ont créé des groupes pour soutenir la culture tibétaine et dénoncer les traitements injustes. Mais le gouvernement a arrêté certains leaders, montrant les risques encourus.

**Prochaine étape** – Malgré les arrestations, le mouvement continue de grandir discrètement. Les jeunes militants devraient continuer à défendre les droits et la justice. Ces manifestations ont ouvert de nouvelles discussions sur la liberté et la solidarité qui pourraient influencer des changements futurs en Chine et ailleurs.

**Une phrase clé** – Les manifestations du Papier blanc ont inspiré une nouvelle génération de jeunes, en Chine et à l’étranger, à défendre les droits humains et à contester les politiques injustes.
articles.personality_title_es: Las protestas del Papel Blanco despiertan a la juventud china y exigen derechos humanos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – A finales de 2022, un incendio mortal en la ciudad china de Urumqi ocurrió durante confinamientos estrictos por Covid-19. Muchas personas culparon a estas duras reglas por dificultar la evacuación del incendio. Esto provocó grandes protestas en varias ciudades chinas.

**Qué pasó** – Miles de personas, principalmente jóvenes, protestaron contra la estricta política de Covid del gobierno y pidieron derechos humanos. Sostenían hojas blancas en blanco para mostrar su enojo sin usar palabras, lo que se convirtió en un símbolo conocido como las protestas del Papel Blanco. Fueron las protestas más grandes en China desde 1989.

**Impacto** – Las protestas ayudaron a acelerar el fin de las estrictas reglas contra el Covid. También despertaron conciencia política entre los jóvenes en China y en las comunidades chinas en el extranjero. Algunos jóvenes activistas han formado grupos para apoyar la cultura tibetana y denunciar el trato injusto. Sin embargo, el gobierno arrestó a algunos líderes, mostrando los riesgos que enfrentan.

**Próximo paso** – A pesar de los arrestos, el movimiento sigue creciendo en silencio. Es probable que los jóvenes activistas continúen luchando por los derechos y la justicia. Las protestas han abierto nuevas conversaciones sobre libertad y solidaridad que podrían influir en futuros cambios en China y más allá.

**Una frase clave** – Las protestas del Papel Blanco han inspirado a una nueva generación de jóvenes dentro y fuera de China a defender los derechos humanos y desafiar políticas injustas.
